t: Proverbs 20
Wine*p is a mocker, strong drink is raging: and whosoever is deceived thereby is not wise.
The*p fear of a king is as the roaring of a lion: whoso provoketh him to anger sinneth against his own soul.
It*p is an honour for a man to cease from strife: but every fool will be meddling.
The*p sluggard will not plow by reason of the cold; therefore shall he beg in harvest, and have nothing.
Counsel*p in the heart of man is like deep water; but a man of understanding will draw it out.
Most*p men will proclaim every one his own goodness: but a faithful man who can find?
The*p just man walketh in his integrity: his children are blessed after him.
A*p king that sitteth in the throne of judgment scattereth away all evil with his eyes.
Who*p can say, I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin?
Divers*p weights, and divers measures, both of them are alike abomination to the Lord.*s
Even*p a child is known by his doings, whether his work be pure, and whether it be right.
The*p hearing ear, and the seeing eye, the Lord*s hath made even both of them.
Love*p not sleep, lest thou come to poverty; open thine eyes, and thou shalt be satisfied with bread.
It*p is naught, it is naught, saith the buyer: but when he is gone his way, then he boasteth.
There*p is gold, and a multitude of rubies: but the lips of knowledge are a precious jewel.
Take*p his garment that is surety for a stranger: and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.
Bread*p of deceit is sweet to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.
Every*p purpose is established by counsel: and with good advice make war.
He*p that goeth about as a talebearer revealeth secrets: therefore meddle not with him that flattereth with his lips.
Whoso*p curseth his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in obscure darkness.
An*p inheritance may be gotten hastily at the beginning; but the end thereof shall not be blessed.
Say*p not thou, I will recompense evil; but wait on the Lord,*s and he shall save thee.
Divers*p weights are an abomination unto the Lord;*s and a false balance is not good.
Man's*p goings are of the Lord;*s how can a man then understand his own way?
It*p is a snare to the man who devoureth that which is holy, and after vows to make enquiry.
A*p wise king scattereth the wicked, and bringeth the wheel over them.
The*p spirit of man is the candle of the Lord,*s searching all the inward parts of the belly.
Mercy*p and truth preserve the king: and his throne is upholden by mercy.
The*p glory of young men is their strength: and the beauty of old men is the gray head.
The*p blueness of a wound cleanseth away evil: so do stripes the inward parts of the belly.
